title: Tuesday, 3rd September 2019

LegalEagle Morning
BE11:15am

And we might have an election that the PM says he doesn't want but clearly does, manufactured from a rebellion that isn't really a rebellion, to force a hastily assembled and largely unexamined manifesto on a county in a state of complete shambles, all to decide a single issue between two equally bad outcomes, in a gambit that'll nearly definitely not work.

BE11:15am

Here's Panmure

VV75 all sounds very British to me
11:16 am
BE11:16am

We have been reluctant to ascribe probabilities to Brexit outcomes throughout the last three years. This has been for two important reasons. Firstly, such analysis gives investors a false impression that a finite basket of outcomes and marginal probabilities can be quantified. Secondly, there are considerable feedback loops that mean the very pursuit of one option by the UK executive can simultaneously increase both its likelihood and the likelihood that the UK legislature will block it. We stick to this approach of focusing on the outcome that we believe is the most stable below.

Soundbuy There's worse.............wife now fancies a Jack Russell Pup.............
BE11:17am

The UK government strategy, such as we can observe it, is to actively pursue a General Election in mid-October where the Conservatives can pitch for a Parliament to support attempts for a better withdrawal deal for the UK. There is little doubt that this will be a powerful electoral message. Even if one ignores the fact the EU are unlikely to grant any movement on the backstop, and that there are increasing signs that no serious attempt at renegotiation is currently being attempted, the core message has the popular blend of “elite bashing”, “standing up for the national interest” and will be supplemented by this new phrase “delivering on the peoples priorities”. This is potentially electoral catnip. It does not take much of a leap of faith to believe this could deliver a majority for the Conservatives which simultaneously strengthens the executive’s perceived negotiating position (if not the actual negotiating power) and reduces the barriers to a fallback position of a No Deal departure. However, it is one hell of a gamble.

BE11:18am

These are some of the things that could derail it:
1) If Conservative constituencies in Scotland, the South West of England and London turn decisively towards the opposition parties then the Conservatives need an awful lot of Midlands and Northern England seats from Labour to return a majority for the Conservatives. David Cameron’s 2015 majority was founded on the collapse of the Liberal Democrat vote (particularly in the SW of England) – and up to 25 Conservative seats could be up for grabs if the Liberal Democrat recent revival translates into a national poll. Clearly Conservatives will try to make it a single issue about the EU and try and tap into the Leave vote in the South West, but Lib Dems will try and run a ground campaign about much more local issues. This local focus was effective for Labour in 2017.
2) In Scotland and London (both significant Remain strongholds) the Conservative vote would be under threat. The Labour Party’s poor polling may help stem the losses in London but there are some very big majorities there for Conservative to overcome. It is very difficult to see any Tories returned North of the Border.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

(@Soundbuy: I'm sorry to hear that, but I'm sure you can find another wife.)

Sails Morning chaps
Soundbuy Ho ho................ :)
BE11:19am

3) There is also the issue of sitting Tory MPs (ex-Cabinet ministers Clarke, Hammond, Gauke, Stewart) who are set against a No Deal who may stand either as Independents and split the centre-right vote, or be retained by their local associations. The Brexit Party have also said they will stand in all constituencies unless the Conservatives commit to a No Deal in their manifesto. The delicate task is to make the manifesto sufficiently No Deal to keep the Brexit Party at bay but avoid splitting the Conservative Party. If the Conservatives are stuck between two stools then the Peterborough and Radnorshire by-elections, where the Leave vote was split, may be illustrative of what happens nationwide.

BE11:19am

Our view is that a General Election represents a massive gamble - one that could deliver a thumping majority for Johnson but also one that could unravel fairly quickly because of the nuances of First Past the Post, incumbent MPs and Local Issues that make a single-issue election a difficult thing to achieve. There is a parallel here with William Hague’s “Last chance to save the Pound” in 2001. An issue that the public cared about clearly – but not enough to swing votes away from issues of health care and education that Labour were talking about.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

We would also be very cautious about assuming that a General Election will to all intents be announced later today. In particular the presumption that if the legislature gets control of the order paper – by passing the proposal to be brought forward by Hilary Benn - then the executive may bring forward a motion either to get 2/3rds of MPs to back a General Election (an election as is no longer the PMs prerogative) or repeal the Fixed Term Parliament Act. In this scenario you may find significant numbers of Labour and Conservative MPs reluctant to have a General Election before the 30 days granted by EU leaders has run its course – or an extension has been secured. This is our baseline scenario - that the present government survives the week and MPs keep their powder dry until mid-October. It is our view that the moment of most acute uncertainty is set to be the third week in October, rather than the coming days. Given the scale of the opportunity in UK assets – a ~25% discount - this would be, in our view, the timetable for taking advantage of the most acute uncertainty.

BE11:21am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:21am

With government and Parliament in disagreement over a no-deal Brexit, we expect elections to decide the way forward, either in October before the scheduled Brexit, or in late 4Q, after an extension. UK apparently heading for a no-deal Brexit...: The Johnson government says that it will leave the EU without a deal on October 31, unless the EU agree to remove the Irish backstop from the current withdrawal agreement. We see the EU as committed to an open border in Ireland and an EU-UK arrangement which protects the single market, and so unlikely to agree to a withdrawal agreement without either the Irish backstop or an Irish Sea border. Since the UK government has rejected both options, this implies that a no-deal Brexit is the default outcome. ...but blocked by Parliament: However, we see a parliamentary majority opposed to a no-deal Brexit, with the government majority down to one, and several Conservative MPs opposed to a no-deal outcome. This group appears to have the numbers to pass the proposed bill this week, requiring the government to seek an extension of the Article 50 negotiating period to January 31, 2020, if it fails to either pass the withdrawal agreement or secure Parliamentary agreement to a no-deal Brexit by October 19.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Why blocking no deal by law may not work: We assume that the Johnson government will seek to avoid asking for an extension, given its commitment to leaving the EU on October 31. And it could in theory have significant opportunity to circumvent the intention of the proposed bill even if it became law, given the difficulty of legislating for an outcome which involves a future negotiation and of enforcing compliance on a reluctant government. Heading for elections. The situation remains fluid.

BE11:22am

We see some chance of an election being triggered this week by a motion for early elections before October 31, perhaps on October 14. If an election is not triggered before prorogation, we see it as likely to be triggered in October after the Queen's Speech debate. At that point, to prevent a no-deal outcome, Parliament could vote down the current government and support a new government; this could be a caretaker government, which would request an extension from the EU and implement that extension into domestic legislation, ahead of December elections.

BE11:22am

Resolution ahead: Regardless of the pathway, we expect an election to decide the way forward, given the UK's more polarised politics. We see a limited chance of continued gridlock, with a binary outcome likely: either a majority for a Brexit without the Irish backstop - probably no deal - or a majority for a second referendum, probably leading to a remain outcome.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

And Goldman.

BE11:23am

Before Parliament is suspended, we expect MPs to legislate against a “no deal”
nBrexit on 31 October. We do not envisage opposition MPs giving their consent to a general election in mid-October. In response, we think the Prime Minister will re-engage in Brexit negotiations with the EU, aiming to confront MPs in late October with a binary choice between a Brexit deal and a pre-Brexit general election.
We see this binary choice as PM Johnson’s best attempt to coerce pro-Leave
nMPs on the Labour backbenches and purist Eurosceptics on the Conservative backbenches into delivering on the result of the Brexit referendum. Faced with the electoral threat posed by the Brexit Party and the Liberal Democrats, we expect a sufficient number of those pivotal MPs to acquiesce to a Brexit deal which — in substance — is similar to the Brexit deal that was repeatedly rejected earlier in the year.
We leave our odds on this “deal” base case unchanged at 45%. In response to
nthe prolonged suspension of Parliament, but in advance of this week’s legislative counter-attack by backbench MPs, we raise our probability on “no deal” from 20% to 25%. We lower our probability on “no Brexit” from 35% to 30%, but we maintain the view that a pre-Brexit general election preserves a plausible path to a second referendum.

2s10s "Circling the plug hole" to quote Bryce

Oh, and just before we move on, should mention this: https://www.politi...peaks-to-playbook/

ELECTION SCOOP — Purdah will not apply: How’s this for messing with the Whitehall rulebook? A senior Downing Street source tells Playbook this morning that Labour MP Mary Creagh’s attempt to stop no-deal preparations due to election purdah rules is going nowhere — as purdah simply will not apply. The No. 10 source says: “The PM has already made clear to senior officials that if he is forced into an election by rebels purdah rules will have no application to no-deal planning. People have forgotten that purdah is a convention, not law, and the law is we are leaving on October 31. Those Remainers clinging to the hope that purdah will save them are clinging to yet another delusion.” Yikes.

BE11:26am

Yeah, so you can't really do that.

BE11:26am

Purdah exists as a firewall between the Civil Service and party politics.

2s10s @BE: As Peter Henessey says the UK constitution is based on govt being 'good chaps' there is no robustness there.
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Removing it means you're not only politicising the Civil Service, you're leaving individual civil servants liable for prosecution under electoral law.

A. M. (gold, seeds, guns,..)
11:35 am
BE11:35am

 Demerger of the UK business. Following a detailed review over several years, Ferguson announced its intention to demerge its UK operations subject to shareholder approval. Upon completion of the demerger,
Wolseley UK will become an independent listed company and Ferguson will be wholly focused on the highermargin and fast-growing North American operations. We note that the group’s UK business accounted for 12% of the group’s revenues and 5% of the group’s Trading Profit in 2018.
 CEO succession plan. The company also announced today that John Martin, Group CEO, will step down on 19 November 2019 and Kevin Murphy (a US national based in Virginia) will succeed him as Group CEO. Mr. Murphy joined the Board in August 2017 when he was appointed CEO of Ferguson's US operations and before that he was COO for 10 years after having joined Ferguson in 1999.
 Listing structure under review. Following a review of the listing structure and significant simplification of the group over several years (and the demerger of Wolseley UK now), Ferguson will be wholly focused on North American markets. In light of this, the Board is considering the most appropriate listing structure. The group is in the early stages of assessing a range of options, associated costs/benefits with further consultations with shareholders in due course.

SPV Anything on Aabar investments?
BE11:36am

Shares already trading through their £59.50 target but they remain overweight, for reasons.

BE11:36am

We value Ferguson on 15x P/E, implying a 10% premium to history to reflect the structural changes, with a larger
proportion of earnings coming from the higher quality US business. Our valuation implies a FCF yield of 5% (FY20) and
an EV/EBITDA multiple of 10x. To justify this valuation on a DCF basis, we need to assume 0% medium-term growth, 1%
terminal growth rate, a long-term margin of 6% (vs. JPMe 2019 of 7.2%), and a reversion in capex to recent historical
levels at 1.3x depreciation.

nightingale20201 Morning all
11:36 am
BE11:37am

And Goldman:

BE11:37am

View
While we take no view on the likelihood of the transaction, we think news of the demerger of the UK operations should be taken well given the drag on group growth and profits in recent years (-6.3% organic decline in 2018). We note that Ferguson trades on a discount to US peers despite a broadly similar growth and returns profile, which we think is mainly due to the challenges the UK business has faced. With the potential demerger of the UK business, we think the stock’s valuation gap to US peers could close (see our note Solid growth and improving returns, yet trades at discount; initiate at Buy).
With regard to the CEO succession, we believe the long tenure of Kevin Murphy at Ferguson should alleviate any concerns investors could have around leadership changes.
Valuation and key risks
Our 12-month price target is 7,700p by applying an 11x EV/EBITDA multiple to C2020 estimates and include potential uses of excess cash, consistent with our methodology across Business Services coverage.

Having now raised more than GBP55m ahead of its planned launch later this year, Cazoo is one of Europe’s best-ever funded start-ups. The latest funding round was led by existing investors including dmg ventures (the venture arm of DMGT), Stride.VC, Octopus Ventures and Entrée Capital with the new funds to be used to further grow the team and invest in marketing and operations.
Comment: With regards to DMGT, this is in line with its strategy of investing in start-ups, and it is on good terms with Alex Chesterman, given the ZPG relationship. For Auto Trader, we see any company that seeks to disrupt the used car market as likely to disrupt Auto Trader’s dominant market position.

BE11:51am

Who say:

BE11:51am

Accrol has delivered FY results that are in line with our forecast at the adjusted EBITDA level, marking the end of a highly complex, well executed turnaround in an unhelpful FX environment. Net debt also continues to fall ahead of our forecasts, with encouraging signs of progress here. We are maintaining our headline forecasts in line with guidance, and see Accrol as a simpler, stronger and more operationally efficient business backed by a proven management team.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Final results: As stated in its pre closed update in June, the results are as expected at the headline level, with adjusted EBITDA bang in line with our forecast of £1.0m. Encouragingly net debt was lower (£27.1m vs. £29.6m forecast) than our forecasts and is expected to reduce further during the next 12 months. It is also important to put into context that these results were delivered despite input cost headwinds of £10.8m during the period, which is testament to management and how they have re-engineered this business during what has been a complex restructuring since 2017.
▪ Progress delivered: The heavy lifting of the turnaround is now complete and has been very well executed in an unhelpful FX environment following further sterling pressure given Brexit uncertainty. The business is now more operationally efficient and fit for purpose, while the Group is beginning to secure more enhanced credit terms from its key suppliers. The Group is expected to remain innovative in winning new business, and capitalise from its low cost, high service “brand killer” approach to different products and markets. Looking further ahead, the Group is exploring opportunities to grow the business and de-risk its exposure to FX and tissue price volatility, which remains at the macro level.

BE11:53am

"Low cost, high service 'brand killer' approach" ... blimey.

BE11:53am

Forecasts: Guidance remains unchanged from the Trading Update in June, and we are maintaining our forecasts as a result. Our 2020 net debt forecasts fall by 3.1% as we allow our assumptions to flow from the improved 2019 position vs. our forecasts. We also introduce our 2022E forecasts for the first time, which assumes marginal price increases with a more stable input cost environment resulting in £14.4m adj. EBITDA.
▪ Investment view: We believe the structural cost savings delivered to date will have a significant impact on the business going into FY 2020, with major restructuring actions now behind them. While challenges remain, we see potential for the Group to return to its pre-IPO foundation to build a more efficient and stronger business from here. If we apply a P/E of 10x to what we our 2022E adj. EPS forecast, we arrive at an intrinsic value of 65p per share.

A. M. @UAWAD: sounds grim -- but how much business did it have prior to this decision?
BE12:02pm

However, given the limited synergies [€20m over four years], the increased exposure to well-capitalised competition that Takeaway.com’s management [and Just Eat’s board] is fully aware of, and board approval at the proposed valuation, it feels to us like the risk/reward of blocking the transaction is unattractive.

Upaswellasdown plenty - it's a bank you will have heard of, expanding its corporate lending book in recent years.
Upaswellasdown BTW, did Wirecard price a bond?
BE12:03pm

All in all, Eminence's position feels a bit like merger arb with an activist veneer.

12:03 pm
undefined
A. M. @UAWAD: hm. so it is grim, then.
BE12:04pm

Oh, forgot Liberum on JE.

BE12:04pm

We think it is increasingly likely the Just Eat bid will not be agreed, just as the agreed private equity bid for Scout24, was similarly rejected by shareholders. We would also agree the bid undervalues the company and it is likely that other bidders will emerge with the soon to be listed Prosus the most likely candidate in our view.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Increasingly, this looks a re-run of what happened with the mainly German-based property and automotive classified portal Scout24 (BUY, €58 TP). In that situation, management agreed a bid for €46 per share from private equity, which was then rejected by shareholders who said the price was too low (the bid valued Scout24 at 14-15x adjusted EBITDA vs. the c. 19x paid for ZPG in the UK, which was an arguably inferior asset). Shareholders look to be justified so far - the Scout24 share price at the close of yesterday was €52.8, a significant premium to the bid;
We agree the bid price looks too low. It implies 770-780p per share vs. our 1360p DCF-based target price. Just Eat's online classified portal model is similar to AutoTrader and Rightmove's, just at a much earlier stage of development. As the clear market leader in most of the markets in which it operates, it should therefore expect to see a hockey stick effect on margins and profits in the medium to longer-term, as its gains a disproportionate share of the benefits.
The stake in iFood is critical. As Eminence points out, iFood is the clear leader in the Brazilian market, which is a huge opportunity (according to its statement, iFood is 17x larger than its nearest competitor). We value Just Eat's stake at £600m, but that is likely to be very conservative;
We see other bidders emerging. We see less chance of an Amazon and Uber Eats coming through (we think the recent announced by the CMA in the UK of an investigation into the online players will discourage the global giants from acquiring Just Eat) but we think Prosus, the soon to be listed spin-off from Naspers, is the most likely candidate for a bid, especially given it is the other major investor in iFood. Acquiring Just Eat would give Prosus immediate market leadership in 12 of the 13 countries plus the technology of SkipTheDishes, which has had phenomenal success in Canada.

Upaswellasdown @AM, yes indeed, grim. I had them pencilled in to finance an acquisition. Ho hum.

Restaurant Group released its H1 results this morning. Group revenue came in at £516m up strongly year on year owing to the acquisition of Wagamama and inline with our forecasts of £517m. Group LFL growth was +4%. PBTe was £28.1m, ahead of our £27.4m forecast. Net debt was £317m. The Group has taken an exceptional pre-tax charge of €116m predominantly relating to the Leisure business driving a statutory loss of £87.7m

A. M. (@BE / ROTR : thanks, have a pleasant day.)
BE12:16pm

(@ElDoc: August 26th, if I remember correctly. Which, if my data are correct, is last month.)

BE12:17pm

Current trading indicates softer start to H2
On current trading, like for like sales growth has slowed to +0.2% in the first 6 weeks of H2 and is now +3.7% for the YTD which is disappointing versus a good H1 outcome. Good performance in its growth businesses including Wagamama was offset by moderate declines in the legacy Leisure business. The acceleration of declines in legacy Leisure was partly owing to weak cinema visits in August and 2 weekends of hot weather and we would note that this is a short trading period.

Blank canvas thanks for everything today
12:17 pm
BE12:17pm

Valuation & investment view
The group has taken a £116m pre-tax charge in H1 of which £102m is a non-cash impairment mostly relating to the legacy Leisure business where management has taken a more cautious view on the prospects for this business.

marktime £102M is one heck of a moderate decline
BE12:18pm

RTN's share price is up 38% since its Easter low-point but it still remains under-valued, in our view. At yesterday's close, RTN is valued (on current forecasts) on a PE of 12.2x, an EV/EBITDA of 7.2x and FCF yield of 9.3% for FY19E, falling to 9.7x, 6.3x and 12.0% for FY20E. Our 185p share price target is based on sum-of-parts methodology. We have used our FY19E forecasts and the 9.9x EBITDA Wagamama acquisition multiple, we also use SSPG (SSPG-LSE : 721p | Hold) as a proxy to value Concessions and referenced Brunning & Price to average pubco multiples. We have applied a lowly 2.7x EBITDA multiple to the Leisure division. Using the Leisure and Wagamama divisions to solve the current share price suggests a zero valuation for the Leisure division.
